column6: Session title
Purposes and Practices
Pronunciation and Rythym
History and Meaning
Text
Ajahn Mun chants for an hour before meditating.
The Buddha asks a monk to recite the [Aṭṭhakavagga (Snp Chapter 4)](https://suttacentral.net/snp-atthakavagga) (Ud 5.6).
of an Indian Brahman novice at Tisarana Monastery who is adept at chanting.
Learning the Paṭimokkha.
Ajahn Pasanno's mother notices that he chants in tune.
An elderly Sri Lankan monk chants to calm a wild elephant.
Chanting 'Itipi so' 108 times.
Chanting sustains a long-time disciple of Ajahn Chah living as a businessman in Bangkok.
Can we approach chanting as praying for someone in a difficult situation?
How can you use chanting to work with long-term physical pain and other people's healing?
Are there any chants that are inappropriate for laypeople to chant?
How can you chant to generate energy?
Is there any danger to chanting?
The fourth precept used to be translated as false and harmful speech. In the new chanting book, it's just lying. Is there a reason for this?
Chanting Book p. 130
MN 41: Saleyyaka Sutta
Sometimes there's no pause between the words we're chanting. Why?
Chanting Book p. 129: Five Precepts.
Are the dots under m and n [ṃ, ṇ] that inscrutable non-English sound that was mentioned earlier?
And that has nothing to do with the pitch going down? That's the carat mark?
It seems like we stretch out 'saha' in the request for the Five Precepts (Chanting Book p. 126).
Can you explain the rythym and scanning of the seventh of the Eight Precepts (Chanting Book p. 135)?
I also get tripped up chanting the fifth precept (Chanting Book p. 130).
Ajahn Pasanno spends Vassa on the Burmese border, but can't chant smoothly with two monks of different nationalities.
We usually chant like that [a simple style] in primary school. It changes when we get to high school.
Do you have any suggestions for audio support for chanting?
[Abhayagiri Chanting Karaoke](https://www.abhayagiri.org/media/chanting/index.html)
The recordings on this website come from the older 2010 [Abhayagiri Chanting Book]().
Are there any standards for the high and low tone marks?
Are the paritta chants not as effective in English?
Do you find these chants as resonant here as in Thailand?
I notice that most of the paritta chants don't have English translations. Is there a place we can find these?
DN 32: Āṭānāṭiya Sutta; SN 46.14-16: Sick
Are there books or online resources for the study of Pāli?
_A New Course in Reading Pāli_ by James W. Gair and W. S. Karunatillake ([pdf](https://buddhistuniversity.net/content/monographs/new-course-in-reading-pali_gair-karunatillake))
Bhikkhu Bodhi's _Reading the Buddha's Discourses in Pāli_ was published in 2020.
There are a couple books that have some parittas in English.
[Book of Protection]()
Suggestion to read the Suttanipāta commentaries available in Bhikkhu Bodhi's translation of this text.
A monk at Poo Jum Gom dislodges a viper by chanting the Khandhaparitta despite believing that it won't work.
Is there a rule of thumb for the pitches for the paritta chanting?
The Verses of Sharing and Aspiration translates paccekabuddha as 'The Solitary Buddha is my noble guide.' What's going on here?
Chanting Book p. 33
